xxl.core.collections.containers
Class CounterContainer

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.collections.containers.AbstractContainer
      xxl.core.collections.containers.ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
          xxl.core.collections.containers.CounterContainer
All Implemented Interfaces:
Container
public class CounterContainer
extends ConstrainedDecoratorContainer

This class decorates a container with a counter functionality and counts every call of an insert, get, update and remove method. But the counter only works correctly when a container is decorated that insertAll, getAll, updateAll and removeAll methods are based the counted insert, get, update and remove methods. This must also hold for the iterators ids() and objects(). This constrained decorator is interesting for statistical use or the performance analysis of containers.

The numbers of calls are stored in public fields and can be reset by the reset method.

Usage example (1). 

     // create a new counter container decorating an empty map container

     CounterContainer container = new CounterContainer(new MapContainer());

     // reset the counter container

     container.reset();

     // insert 20 elements and print the counters

     for (int i = 0; i < 20; i++)
         container.insert(new Integer(i));
     System.out.println(container);
     System.out.println();

     // create an iteration over the ids of the counter container

     java.util.Iterator iterator = container.ids();

     // get 10 elements and print the counters

     for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++)
         if (iterator.hasNext())
             container.get(iterator.next());
     System.out.println(container);
     System.out.println();

     // update 5 elements and print the counters

     for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++)
         if (iterator.hasNext())
             container.update(iterator.next(), new Integer(i));
     System.out.println(container);
     System.out.println();

     // remove an element and print the counters

     if (iterator.hasNext())
         container.remove(iterator.next());
     System.out.println(container);
     System.out.println();

     // close the open container after use

     container.close();

Field Detail

FACTORY_METHOD

public static final Function<Container,CounterContainer> FACTORY_METHOD
A factory method to create a new CounterContainer. It may only be invoked with a parameter list (for further details see Function) of containers. The parameter list of containers will be used to initialize the decorated container by calling the constructor CounterContainer(list.get(0)).

See Also:
Function

inserts

public int inserts
The number of times an insert method is called on this container since the last reset. This number is identical to the number of elements that are inserted since the last reset because the insertAll method calls for every element the insert method.

gets

public int gets
The number of times a get method is called on this container since the last reset. This number is identical to the number of elements that are got since the last reset because the getAll method calls for every element the get method.

updates

public int updates
The number of times an update method is called on this container since the last reset. This number is identical to the number of elements that are updated since the last reset because the updateAll method calls for every element the update method.

removes

public int removes
The number of times a remove method is called on this container since the last reset. This number is identical to the number of elements that are removed since the last reset because the removeAll method calls for every element the remove method.

reserves

public int reserves
The number of times a reserve method is called on this container since the last reset.

Constructor Detail

CounterContainer

public CounterContainer(Container container)
Constructes a new CounterContainer that decorates the specified container.

Parameters:
container - the container to be decorated with the counter.
Method Detail

reset

public void reset()
Resets the counters for insert, get, update and remove methods. A call of this method sets every counter to 0.

get

public java.lang.Object get(java.lang.Object id,
                            boolean unfix)
                     throws java.util.NoSuchElementException
Returns the object associated to the identifier id. An exception is thrown if there is not object stored with this id. If unfix is set to true, the object can be removed from the underlying buffer. Otherwise (!unfix), the object has to be kept in the buffer.

Specified by:
get in interface Container
Overrides:
get in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
Parameters:
id - identifier of the object.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
the object associated to the specified identifier.
Throws:
java.util.NoSuchElementException - if the desired object is not found.

insert

public java.lang.Object insert(java.lang.Object object,
                               boolean unfix)
Inserts a new object into the container and returns the unique identifier that the container has been associated to the object. The identifier can be reused again when the object is deleted from the buffer. If unfixed, the object can be removed from the buffer. Otherwise, it has to be kept in the buffer until an unfix() is called.
After an insertion all the iterators operating on the container can be in an invalid state.
This method also allows an insertion of a null object. In the application would really like to have such objects in the container, some methods have to be modified.

Specified by:
insert in interface Container
Overrides:
insert in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
Parameters:
object - is the new object.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Returns:
the identifier of the object.

remove

public void remove(java.lang.Object id)
            throws java.util.NoSuchElementException
Removes the object with identifier id. An exception is thrown when an object with an identifier id is not in the container.
After a call of remove() all the iterators (and cursors) can be in an invalid state.

Specified by:
remove in interface Container
Overrides:
remove in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
Parameters:
id - an identifier of an object.
Throws:
java.util.NoSuchElementException - if an object with an identifier id is not in the container.

reserve

public java.lang.Object reserve(Function getObject)
Reserves an id for subsequent use. The container may or may not need an object to be able to reserve an id, depending on the implementation. If so, it will call the parameterless function provided by the parameter getObject.

Specified by:
reserve in interface Container
Overrides:
reserve in class ConstrainedDecoratorContainer
Parameters:
getObject - A parameterless function providing the object for that an id should be reserved.
Returns:
the reserved id.

public void update(java.lang.Object id,
                   java.lang.Object object,
                   boolean unfix)
            throws java.util.NoSuchElementException
Overwrites an existing (id,*)-element by (id, object). This method throws an exception if an object with an identifier id does not exist in the container.

Specified by:

Overrides:

object - the new object that should be associated to id.
unfix - signals whether the object can be removed from the underlying buffer.
Throws:
